21260: Fanatical Devotion.author: Richtmark
21260: Fanatical Devotion.text_parsed:
Question: Can the sacrificed and targeted creature to be regenerated be the same creature?

I know regeneration can't be used to bring a sacrificed creature back to life, but that's beyond the point. My purpose is, rather, I run this in an Enchantment deck, and one of its uses is to have a way to kill my own Academy Rector so its graveyard ability triggers. If there are other creatures on the table it wouldn't matter since I could target some other creature with the regenerate effect.

However, what if the Academy Rector is the only targetable creature on the table? Can I sacrifice it and simultaneously let the regenerate effect target it? Is it a legal target for the regenerate effect? How is the payment of the activation cost timed relative to the target selection of the effect? Is the Academy Rector still in play when the target is selected, or is it already in the graveyard and thus untargetable?

My gut feeling tells me it's the latter, but I'm not sure.
21260: Fanatical Devotion.text_posted:
Question: Can the sacrificed and targeted creature to be regenerated be the same creature?

I know regeneration can't be used to bring a sacrificed creature back to life, but that's beyond the point. My purpose is, rather, I run this in an Enchantment deck, and one of its uses is to have a way to kill my own [autocard]Academy Rector[/autocard] so its graveyard ability triggers. If there are other creatures on the table it wouldn't matter since I could target some other creature with the regenerate effect. 

However, what if the Academy Rector is the only targetable creature on the table? Can I sacrifice it and simultaneously let the regenerate effect target it? Is it a legal target for the regenerate effect? How is the payment of the activation cost timed relative to the target selection of the effect? Is the Academy Rector still in play when the target is selected, or is it already in the graveyard and thus untargetable?

My gut feeling tells me it's the latter, but I'm not sure.

21260: Fanatical Devotion.author: TheLibertinistic
21260: Fanatical Devotion.text_parsed: Richtmark will likely never see this, but here's his answer: The targeted creature can be the sacrificed one, though it'll do as little as he thinks. Technically, targets are declared before costs are paid, because an ability needs legal targets at declaration in order to be put on the stack. The Cost:Effect templating is usually pretty helpful in that it indicates you pay costs then get effects, but it's misleading in this case.
21260: Fanatical Devotion.text_posted: Richtmark will likely never see this, but here's his answer: The targeted creature can be the sacrificed one, though it'll do as little as he thinks. Technically, targets are declared before costs are paid, because an ability needs legal targets at declaration in order to be put on the stack. The Cost:Effect templating is usually pretty helpful in that it indicates you pay costs then get effects, but it's misleading in this case.

21260: Fanatical Devotion.author: OmegaSerris
21260: Fanatical Devotion.text_parsed:
@Richtmark

I'm going to try and answer your question based on how I read the rules. Please, anyone correct me if I'm wrong.

Short Answer: If your goal is only to sac the creature, yes you can target it and it will die.

Long Answer: Based on 602.2 in the rules, a target is picked before the cost is paid. So AT THE TIME of choosing targets, the creature has yet to be sacrificed, and hence, a legal target. THEN the cost is paid, you pick a creature to sacrifice. If the costs are paid, it hits the stack. This is the first chance anyone has to respond to it. After everyone passes priority, it tries to resolve. The target it illegal (doesn't exist anymore) and it is countered.

I hope this is what you were looking for. :-)

Edit: I just noticed TheLibertinistic's answer. It appears mine supports it, so there you go.

[b]Long Answer:[/b] Based on 602.2 in the rules, a target is picked before the cost is paid. So AT THE TIME of choosing targets, the creature has yet to be sacrificed, and hence, a legal target. THEN the cost is paid, you pick a creature to sacrifice. If the costs are paid, it hits the stack. This is the first chance anyone has to respond to it. After everyone passes priority, it tries to resolve. The target it illegal (doesn't exist anymore) and it is countered.

I hope this is what you were looking for. :-)

[b]Edit:[/b] I just noticed TheLibertinistic's answer. It appears mine supports it, so there you go.

21263: Avenger en-Dal.author: Mode
21263: Avenger en-Dal.text_parsed:
Well since he's a spellshaper with repeatable removal you should think he's pretty solid, but he combines the two less appealing aspects of Exile and Swords to Plowshares - the restriction to attaking creatures and the lifegain to your opponent. I'm glad they removed the nonwhite restriction at least.

But it's still an incredibly slow card. Two mana for a 1/1, then your opponent gets time until his next turn but one to get rid of it, which isn't too hard in the case of such a tiny creature.

And even if you get to activate his ability, it still doesn't help you against aggro that much when you don't get the life and instead fuel your opponent with it, especially since you can't build yourself up when you have to pay three mana and discard a card for his ability each turn.

This might have been a good choice in limited, but is barely useful in constructed.

21271: Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero.author: Guest1162619373
21271: Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero.text_parsed: She was banned in Masques because the Legend rule at the time stated that a legendary permanent in play would stay in play should a second instance of the permanent enter play and the second one would go to the graveyard as a state-based effect.  So, in that block, if both players were running Rebel decks the player who got Lin Sivvi out first generally had a massive advantage over the other player who would have to kill the opponent's Lin Sivvi before they could play theirs and have it survive.  Today, they would both die if a second Lin Sivvi was put into play.

21271: Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero.author: TokenMaster
21271: Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero.text_parsed:
Quite powerful on her own, but not necessarily broken. Training Grounds, on the other hand, makes this card insane and singlehandedly breaks rebels.

Lin Sivvi is also a 1-card combo setup with Children of Korlis, which you can cycle turn after turn as long as the opponent doesn't deal lethal damage. I actually made a deck where this is preferable to Privileged Position (and somewhat to Asceticism): A defender deck (yeah, seriously) that just uses creatures and lands as permanents, and doesn't use any targeting on them.
Unless you manage to cast this twice, Spiritual Asylum would be strictly better in this deck even if Privileged Position would cost less. That is one very marginal case, but that's not relevant in constructed:
as long as a card can find its home in a deck, it serves the purpose.
I agree that this card isn't too playable though, so this could indeed have been cheaper.

21277: Spiritual Asylum.author: SliverApocalypse
21277: Spiritual Asylum.text_parsed:
The thing about Privileged Position is you can not run it in a Mono-White EDH. Of course, with the hype of Nath and Rhys the Redeemed for GW decks, that doesn't mean much, because Mono-White is not going to be too common unless it uses something like Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant for a general.

The only issues with this VS Privileged Position:
- does not protect your artifacts and enchantments
- shroud means you can't aura enchant your creatures
- you attack, the enchantment breaks

Big gap, but you have to realize the time gap between the printing of the two cards.

You play this to buy yourself time to recover from dropping a Day of Judgement on the field and being left wide open otherwise, as you play defensive and can no longer have your creatures countered or pinged as they enter the field, or simply to prevent red target damage whilst forcing the enemy to attack you. If you play your field buff enchants right, this is awesome.

21278: Trickster Mage.author: N03y3D33R
21278: Trickster Mage.text_parsed:
@ DarthParallax
That's only assuming they want to play a partially white deck/heavy blue deck, or worse, add a bunch of otherwise unhelpful cards to a deck just to be able to play that enchantment.

This card has speed going for it.
It's going to be in play early on and denying your opponent access to their early mana or attack force, or their mid-game fatties.
It also only requires you to have a single blue mana to cast it and use it each turn, meaning it functions well in any multicolored decks that run blue, not only for manipulating the enemy but also for untapping a land you currently only have one of to play a second spell of that color (For Example: On my first turn I played an Island and then trickster mage, but by turn 3 I only have one swamp and two islands. I want to play a Drekavac to discard Strength of Lunacy and turn him into a 5/4 Beast with protection from white but can't because I do not have two swamps available. By tapping one of those Islands plus Trickster Mage and discarding a card I can untap the swamp after casting Drekavac and use it to pay the madness cost of Strength of Lunacy.)
This is definitely one of the better spellshapers out there, and it's easy to accommodate in many decks just because it's so cheap and fast.

21280: Cloudskate.author: RaymondKHessel
21280: Cloudskate.text_parsed: Very cool art from Carl Critchlow on a very effective creature.  Stated nicely by Tiggurix above already: mono-blue aggro is a viable (and surprisingly powerful) deck type, partly because people rarely see it coming.  Cloudskate fits in nicely, and is common for pauper format fun.  Cheap fliers like this can hand you the game before your opponent gets a suitable defense established.  Also, blue has so many ways to bounce creatures that reloading this guy is a snap when he's almost out of fade counters.
21280: Cloudskate.text_posted: Very cool art from Carl Critchlow on a very effective creature.  Stated nicely by Tiggurix above already: mono-blue aggro is a viable (and surprisingly powerful) deck type, partly because people rarely see it coming.  Cloudskate fits in nicely, and is common for pauper format fun.  Cheap fliers like this can hand you the game before your opponent gets a suitable defense established.  Also, blue has so many ways to bounce creatures that reloading this guy is a snap when he's almost out of fade counters.

21287: Seal of Removal.author: majinara
21287: Seal of Removal.text_parsed:
To th guy mentioning aether spellbomb... the big difference is, this card doesn't require mana to activate. Here you can play this card, and then tap out and use all your mana the most efficiently as possible. With the spellbomb, you have decide each turn "should I tap out and play that card I have on my hand? but then I can't use the spellbomb... or should I wait another turn so I have more mana..."

In general I like those seals a lot. Sure, they ain't as surprising as the instant version of the spells, but they have a greater impact on the playstyle of your opponents, especially in multiplayer. If people see you could bounce their enchanted / equipped creature any moment, they'll rather attack someone else but you. And if they see you can bounce your creature any time, they'll use their removal rather on someone elses creatures.

21287: Seal of Removal.text_parsed: When you run one enchantment, you run a lot of them so you can avoid them Naturalize/Disenchanting everything you have. It's a great distraction from your late game fatchantments and if they decide it's not worth taking care of, it's a great way to set your opponent back 3 turns on their BSA when they drop it, wait a turn, attack and have it bounced while they have no mana left. And you get to do it all with the mana you had turn 1 that you couldn't use for anything else anyway. 4.5/5 for great cost and utility. Seal of Unsummon is awesome.
21287: Seal of Removal.text_posted: When you run one enchantment, you run a lot of them so you can avoid them [autocard]Naturalize[/autocard]/[autocard]Disenchant[/autocard]ing everything you have. It's a great distraction from your late game fatchantments and if they decide it's not worth taking care of, it's a great way to set your opponent back 3 turns on their BSA when they drop it, wait a turn, attack and have it bounced while they have no mana left. And you get to do it all with the mana you had turn 1 that you couldn't use for anything else anyway. 4.5/5 for great cost and utility. Seal of [autocard]Unsummon[/autocard] is awesome.

21287: Seal of Removal.author: Blackworm_Bloodworm
21287: Seal of Removal.text_parsed:
It hurts to wait for a reprint of this card. I would argue that this is the best of the seals; after the first turn, it's a free unsummon. As Kryptnyt said, it affects the choices your opponent makes since they can see it on the field.

If they try to destroy it, you can just sac it in response and bounce their creature. If they don't have any creatures to bounce, then they just wasted removal on a 1 CMC enchantment. Either way, it's a loss for your opponent. This card, save for one turn, has no affect on your mana whatsoever. Much better than the spellbomb.
21287: Seal of Removal.text_posted:

Either way, it's a loss for your opponent. This card, save for one turn, has no affect on your mana whatsoever. [b]Much[/b] better than the spellbomb.

21287: Seal of Removal.author: Equinox523
21287: Seal of Removal.text_parsed:
All the Seals are Purloined Letters - the threat of their use is as potent as their actual use. What's nice about this one is you don't need to keep one mana open to use it like Unsummon, freeing up mana for counterspells without losing too much tempo, as long as you don't mind missing your 1-drop. Equally useful in the late game, and can just kill tokens. A very versatile card and much better than it looks. Play with a new in your blue deck, and you will see how much it makes your opponent play around it.

(PS: Bonus points for everyone who got the Poe reference.)

21287: Seal of Removal.author: Fictionarious
21287: Seal of Removal.text_parsed:
SOOO good for a one-drop in what it does I'll go so far as to rate it a five. Just for giggles I decided to take Vedalken Mastermind (the usual centerpiece of my deck) out and replaced it with four of this because it was "faster". This was in a 3-game matchup between my deck and a deck my friend made called "out of control", specifically to defeat mine, filled with cards like Volcanic Fallout, Guttural Response, that pro blue/black stag thing, manlands, etc.
I lost the match 1 game to 2, but I credit this card with the only win I did get.

Building a typical Merfolk deck and including Seahunter doesn't mean you're building around it. =P

But yes, it's a fantastic card, no questions asked. If your Wanderwine Prophets is making contact and you have a Seahunter out, it's pretty much GG as you can keep getting out "extra turn fodder", giving you what is more or less infinite turns.

Even though it's not a Merfolk, include it in most Merfolk decks. It's that simple.

21302: Pale Moon.author: Mode
21302: Pale Moon.text_parsed:
A far too specific ability to be useful without being a cantrip or at least a slowtrip.
It might be chosen by Ben Bleiweiss as #1 crap card, and he said it'd still be pretty useless as cantrip, but I've got still some cards in mind i consider slightly worse than this one.

Given that you actually play against a deck with a no or very few artifacts that only uses nonbasics (which is already quite rare, but still not as unlikely as several other bad cards which act in a very specific way in non-block-constructed play), you can at least for one turn Silence him/her and prevent paying certain activated or triggered abilities. And yeah, talking about Silence and such, this one is a hundred times better for instance. And you are even affected by this drawback as well, but consider that you might already tapped out or kept your basic lands untapped for further spells.

But of course this one is certainly still not playable an incredibly bad pick afterall.
Gotta spash blue for my Chimney Imp deck...

21302: Pale Moon.author: RPGfan
21302: Pale Moon.text_parsed: This card... is the worst card I've ever seen. It was released at a time when most nonbasic lands rarely gave mana OTHER than colorless and it's of limited use even today since it doesn't deny mana, just colored mana. Even with the modern proliferation of dual color lands it sucks because it has no lasting influence and shuts down YOUR dual color lands as well, thus preventing you from casting good counterspells. It was also released in the same block (and rarity slot) as Parallax Tide which works MUCH better as a land hoser. If it was an Enchantment or cantrip then it would be still be bad, but it would at least do SOMETHING. As it stands, the card may as well read "Wave goodbye to two mana".

21304: Rising Waters.author: blurrymadness
21304: Rising Waters.text_parsed:
Neat with Paradox Haze and neater still with Pendrell Mists. Because they're your triggers you can stack it so they actually can't pay the mana; making this a much more effective lock than Winter Orb. What's more? These stack; so you can have multiples to untap multiple lands while other players can *never* hit you with a non-haste creature if you don't want them to. Kill them at your leisure.

Winter Orb is better in some scenarios; mostly those that involve getting the game slowed down sooner. This is better at locking the game with less pieces and is far more abusable with other enchants (including redundant copies of itself.)

Use next to a baby-jace for an affordable ($) and on curve way to card advantage town; which I hear good things about.

21309: Spiteful Bully.author: Fanaticmogg
21309: Spiteful Bully.text_parsed:
Steel Wall, Kraken Hatchling, Perimiter Captain, and Yoked Ox all work if you want to drop this guy on the second turn. Dutiful Thrull, Odious Trow, Rimebound Dead, Urborg Skeleton, and Will-o'-the-Wisp can also regenerate through the damage. Glittering Lynx and Clergy of the Holy Nimbus also work, especially since they can also attack, but then your opponent can just pay the mana and kill them, so you'll want a backup plan, like the Swans or Stuffy.

Overall, though, the requirements are a bit steep for a 3-power 2-CC creature. Play something else, and get a good 1-drop to go with it.

this card seems great to me-
it gives you a painful cost (sac-ing a creature...which, if your playing as if your an amoral prick who doesnt 'care about his monsters', should be easy- black usually rewards amoral prickish strategies >:)
and then ON TOP of that, it gives you a REAL challenge-
figuring out how to make this hurt them more than you- but this is MTG. come on. anythings doable.

so for ALL THAT, you get, in the end, a power that is much better than hymn to tourach- exile trumps discard.

huge upside, huge downside. this is the kind of card mono-black mages should revel in. I feel like cards such as Doom Blade have spoiled black mages into thinking too much like Red mages- 'kill them now, damn the future, their wont BE a future' which is ALMOST like black, EXCEPT it means that black players no longer seem to care much about playing cards like this, when cards like this are about the only thing that really lets you tell the difference between black and red. red just doesnt have the tech to play this. black does, if you look for it. without hellbent or madness even, though of course there's no reason not to play good synergies if they work.

21318: Divining Witch.author: Jorgumander
21318: Divining Witch.text_parsed:
When this card first came out, I collected it until I managed to trade for 4 of them. It fascinated me because it seemed so useless and I really wanted to figure out how to use it effectively. I've had those 4 cards in my binder of rares ever since. I think (with the help of others on these forums) I finally have a decent combo for it. Blue/black suicide deck

Put Divining Witch into play, and make it hexproof with a Mask of Avacyn.

Put a Laboratory Lunatic into play. Preferably making it hexproof as well (or having counter magic ready). Use Divining Witch to look for something NOT in your deck. Someone suggested "Black Lotus" to watch the faces of all of your opponents when you say THAT! haha. Then, after you've milled your last card, use some cheap instant, like a Mental Note to make yourself draw a card. Win. Now REALLY enjoy their faces! :)

21318: Divining Witch.author: XaiviarNightwing

The combo for this card is pure black actually.
Get Necrotic Ooze
Sac this guy
Discard Void Maw.
Get anything or nothing.
Have Mortal Combat out.
Use combo at end of opponents turn.
Use Void Maws ability to put all the cards into your graveyard since the Ooze removed them.
Keep an Eldrazi to keep this from going bad so you can shuffle your grave into your deck if you need to.

21324: Massacre.author: Ferlord
21324: Massacre.text_parsed:
At first, I thought this was a sometimes better, sometimes worse reprint of Infest.

But no! Infest came out 2 years after! How interesting!

That being said, this card works wonders with Ascendant Evincar, the creature pictured. See, your creatures are pumped (most likely, since you're playing black) and your opponents are not (unless they're playing black).

If he is out, the only creatures you have that will die are cards with an initial toughness of 1.
On the flip-side, all your opponents non-black creatures that have a toughness of 3 will die, no questions asked.

Very nice, and the free cost is just gravy.

21328: Volrath the Fallen.author: linksdeity
21328: Volrath the Fallen.text_parsed:
My favorite black creature and Magic storyline character.

He one hits with Draco and Emrakul, the Aeons Torn, but works well with any big creature and recur-able necromancy (Phyrexian Reclamation, Revive the Fallen, and appropriately Volrath's Stronghold).

Feed him a Filth with an Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth on the field. Shizo, Death's Storehouse works very well with him, as does Rime Transfusion and Dauthi Embrace.

Once you've pumped him up and attacked don't be afraid to Rite of Consumption him.

21328: Volrath the Fallen.text_parsed:
An amazing reanimation support card. Unlike Putrid Imp, doing the effect multiple times is actually beneficial.

Putrid Imp is still better, since the effect is free, and the Imp has 1 CMC instead of 6.

That being said, Volrath may win the game for you by himself while Putrid Imp is just solely support. I guess if your opponent let by a 1/1 flyer every time it attacked (and then a 2/2 when you have threshold) then it'd win, but that's a lot less likely than a pump-able 6/4.

21333: Laccolith Grunt.author: blurrymadness
21333: Laccolith Grunt.text_parsed:
Laccoliths are big fans of Quietus Spikes.

Someone blocks with only one guy? You kill it. If they don't they eat a TON of life. If you combine this tactic with Brass Squire and multiple Laccoliths you can quickly cause an impossible puzzle for your opponent:
-You let the equipped Laccolith's ability kill something, then you respond to another's by attaching the equipment and letting it have deathtouch.
-You can also simply move the equipment if they left one unblocked and they'll eat a ton of lifeloss.

So if you have 2 lac's and a squire + spike, you cause your opponent to lose 1-2 creatures per turn or each 3-6 + half of his remaining life each turn (meaning that it'll take 2-3 turns to kill him at any life total below ~40. (Say 4 damage, then they drop from 40->36->18, 18->14->7)

Basically, mix equipments with these guys that tell your opponent to block them but in such a way that you can really exploit that blocking. Notice that you could also use bounces or flicker to save these guys after they do their damage, creating other unwinnable scenarios for your opponent.

Even grafted wargear says "It takes 2 4/4s to kill me and I can kill your titan in response"

21339: Laccolith Rig.author: Mode
21339: Laccolith Rig.text_parsed:
Really neat card, because of the (flavorly odd) fact that the enchantment and not the creature has the Laccolith trigger, so you can still decide where the damage goes when cast on an opponent's creature.
(Well maybe not necessarily that odd, considering that you are creator of the Rig and have control over it :P)

It can both work for and against aggro. Only downside is that you need a creature for it to work defensively.
But you could get that by fetching a Dryad Arbor with Wooded Foothills, or by casting Green Sun's Zenith maybe.
You could regard it as a red-flavored Spirit Link.

While we're at white one-drop enchantments: This also works with Reconnaissance and Gustcloak creatures. And Laccolith creatures :D
You could get your opponent in a quandary with creatures that have both triggers for getting blocked and dealing damage to them. Slith Strider is currently the only one of that kind though.
A similarly rare find: creatures with damage prevention drawbacks that overlap with the Laccolith trigger - Leery Fogbeast does well if that's your only attacker.
Creatures with Venom triggers like Cóckatrice or Tangle Asp also work.
And Witherscale Wurm doesn't need to fear about Wither with the rig either.

When cast on your opponent's creature, this is also fun with Siren effects. Try Rage Nimbus for hilarious results.

Red players might sideboard against opponents running Darksteel artifact creatures, knights with Knight Exemplar or other hordes of hard-to-remove creatures, or most any weenie deck. Too mana-intensive for splash but in the end it's a 4/4 for 5 CMC which isn't terrible on its own.

I really like this guy - he has the effect of a Thundermare at a fraction of the cost, and he is a member of one of the most prolific tribes, to boot!

In one of my many goblin decks over the years, I used to use Goblin Wizard to sneak him into play on an opponent's turn, pre-combat step. They wouldn't be able to attack, and on my next turn I'd have no blockers (or very few) standing between my goblins and my opponent!

21353: Shrieking Mogg.author: zk3
21353: Shrieking Mogg.text_parsed:
This is a deceptive card that may trick some into thinking it's good.
This is a sorta narrow card, and one might think a singleton in a Goblin deck is good enough to be tutored with Goblin Matron and then aether vialed in for the alpha strike.

However, most goblin players don't ramp up their vial up to only 2 and hold it there; most go up to 3 or 4 (for Ringleader). There aren't many 2 drops in most goblin decks - only either Piledriver and cycling Gempalm Incinerator to connect with a lackey. Furthermore, Goblin Warchief 2-cost spells only R, which don't really need to be vialed in - another strike against this card.

21356: Mana Cache.author: Tiplady
21356: Mana Cache.text_parsed:
I've never been a fan of cards that affect both players evenly, it's always possible to tip the scales in your own favor due to specific situations, but this card is fairly open ended, and depending on how the rules work with removing multiple counters at once, the M10 (no-manaburn) rules could really interfere with even the best uses of this card.

RANDOM SIDENOTE PARAGRAPH:
It'd be interesting to see a permanent that caused the mana-burn rules to come into play while it's out, but they'd have to add even more tools for that decktype to work, seeing as it wasn't the greatest issue in the game when mana-burn was static. In exchange for being suseptible to removal effects, I think 2damage for each unspent mana would be fair. Especially if it's a creature without shroud or indestructable. Though it could get good if the effect stacked for each copy of the card you had in play, similar to Citadel of Pain.

This card had it's uses in the past, required specific decktypes due to the opponent being able to effect it, and is nearly useless in the current game.

21357: Stronghold Gambit.author: EGarrett01
21357: Stronghold Gambit.text_parsed:
@Mode

You obviously didn't get what he said. You don't view Magic cards by their worst-case scenario because it will never occur, usually because you put them into decks that maximize their strengths and you don't cast them if there's that risk in the first place. You view cards by what is likely to happen when you actually choose to play them. If your opponent doesn't have a creature in hand (either b/c he's playing a creatureless deck, he's got no cards in hand or you Gitaxian Probe him or Duress him and confirm he doesn't) then you can put any creature in your hand into play free.

This card is super-underrated and actually pretty scary.

21359: Stampede Driver.author: Gabriel422
21359: Stampede Driver.text_parsed:
The power player in my very first theme deck that I spent the very first $8 on. Just looking at the card seems to take me back to 2000, when I was 13 and all the cool kids (the boys, at least) were playing Magic and a close friend of mine taught me how to play.

My mom heard about the game, and saw me excited over a Prophecy theme deck displayed in a small grocery store in my home town.

It went like:
Me: "This is it!"
Mom: "Right, Magic: the Gathering... how much does it cost?"
Me: "Looks like it's $8."
Mom: "Um, sure."

And for some nights after that, I had all the dreams about Giant Growthing things to beat their Blastoderms, and how some Lotus Petals would speed out the beasts. Not that I owned any of those cards, and I ended up writing "G +3/+3" and "2G +7/+7" on some of my cards.

Me: "This is Giant Growth, and this is +7/+7."
One of my classmates: "Actually Might of Oaks costs 3G."

Those were the days when I stealed a win from an opponent through a tapped Shivan Wurm with a Thicket Elemental pumped with Invigorate and Wax / Wane. Those were the days when I killed two extremely menacing Air Elementals with my Spitting Spider, nailing a Energy Field in the process, while still ending up losing from having all lands sacrificed to the spider. Those were the days when I sat across the table, totally undaunted, against a player with a full grip of counterspells and 10+ untapped Islands, and still hoping to 'sneak in' my Vitalizing Wind.

Ten years and thousands of new cards later, my life have changed as much as Magic has. I played decks involving Treva's Charm, Phantom Nishoba, Wretched Anurid, Pentad Prism, Kiki-jiki, Angel of Despair, Momentary Blink, Kitchen Finks, Putrid Leech, Beastmaster Ascension, and way many more. All of them are fond memories, but some certain Nemesis and Prophecy green cards will always be special. For they were the first, and the first always takes one down a long, long memory lane.

While I can put Rancor on *any* card and have good effect; it's really nice on a guy you know is going to die; as it's a pump that puts 4 damage down range that even 2/2 first strikers can't get around; so they have to eat it.

If you:
T1- this guy (forest)
T2- rancor, attack for 4 (hickory woodlot)
T3- attack for 4, horned kavu, rancor, this guy (mountain)
T4- cliffrunner, attack for 12

T4 win with no card-disadvantage pumps or burn..

..with Kavus and Beasts. Two of the most disresepected and-yet-obviously-playable tribes in magic.

21363: Blastoderm.author: stygimoloch
21363: Blastoderm.text_parsed: I still play this a 4-of in a lot of green stompy decks even today. There aren't a great many ways around this when it hits the table other than blockers, and even then you can often get a 2-for-1. Successive Blastoderms on turns four and five are a serious headache for the vast majority of decks, wiping out a number of blockers even if they don't hit the player, especially if preceded by a turn-three Wirewood Savage or followed up with an Overrun. I've always found that Green can use this card much more effectively than white can Calciderm, too.

This strategy was developed by Magic Hall Of Fame player Zvi Moshowitz.

21366: Seal of Strength.author: feeble2002
21366: Seal of Strength.text_parsed:
This is slightly worse than giant growth, although it is the same casting cost as giant growth, and it can be sac'd as an instant. Main differences:

1) Lose the element of surprise. You can' t surprise ambush a 4/4 fatty with your 2/2. Seal is not an instant, unlike giant growth.
2) Gain greater mana efficiency.You can play Seal whenever a single land is available, rather than keeping a land untapped just in case your opponent attacks. You could also play it on turn 1, before a creature is available.

Seal does provide a sense of intimidation. Your opponent knows you can pump your creature when he attacks. Giant growth, however, provides masked, hidden intimidation. If you have one land untapped he will always wonder if you have growth...

Overall, it is a good complement to giant growth. But, nothing special.

The whole point of combat tricks is surprise. Oh, your 4/4 is attacking? I block with my 2/2, giant growth.

21368: Fog Patch.author: sonorhC
21368: Fog Patch.text_parsed:
This still lets you do damage with any blocking creatures you want, which Tanglesap wouldn't. On the other hand, if any of your blockers have trample, Tanglesap would let them block safely, while this would still have them take damage.

You can also benefit from playing Tanglesap during your own attack, if you have a lot of tramplers, but it's much harder to get any benefit out of this card that way.

21368: Fog Patch.author: casual_melvin

I love unique effects.
The phantom blocker effect is special enough by itself, and this the only one of those that doesn't target.
This means this is the only way to block progenitus or invisible stalker.

Other effects can prevent the damage or actually get rid of the creature, but I'm an obstinate baloth. I like doing exactly the opposite of what I'm told.

this card appears quite weak actually, yet it can be very beneficial if you are playing a beast tribal deck. they're normally quite slow at the early game, but if you can afford an additional 2/2 body this can really help defending the aggro for a while. i prefer my opponent having 5 more live rather than letting him win :D

and of course it synergizes great with False Cure or Kavu Predator.

it could possibly have a cheaper mana cost of 2G instead or higher toughness, though...

edit: Needlebite Trap does a great job with that card. Play a Bayou or Overgrown Tomb on turn one and start off with 25 life and a 2/2 body!

21375: Pack Hunt.author: Mode
21375: Pack Hunt.text_parsed:
I like that this tutor gives you the same card advantage as Harmonize at an easier cost.
Obvious drawback is that you need the right creature on the battlefield.

I'm surprised nobody mentioned using this card with the ability word Grandeur yet.

This can give you 6 Swamps right on the battlefield and with that a +6/+6 boost for Korlash, Heir to Blackblade for example.

It gives you 3 powerful Wurm tokens with Baru, Fist of Krosa.

Both legends even combine with each other: given that you cast another Pack Hunt, you'll either end up with thre huge Wurms or you have your creatures get +6/+6 and trample when fetching Bayou and Overgrown Tomb.

Oriss, Samite Guardian might even be the best one, since she can lock down your opponent for three whole turns with Pack Hunt. Enough time to return one of her duplicates to your hand, or just win the game in the meantime.

Linessa, Zephyr Mage might be able to do something similar, since a boomerang for a creature, an artifact, a land and an enchantment each will throw your opponent back devastingly.

Tarox Bladewing can also swing for the win when you cast Pack Hunt if your opponent doesn't have any flyers. And if he becomes the target of spot removal you're left with nothing, as opposed to the other legends (excluding Oriss).

21377: Animate Land.author: Atali
21377: Animate Land.text_parsed:
~ + Doom Blade: same CMC as Stone Rain, loses card advantage for speed.
~ + Incinerate: same CMC as Stone Rain, loses card advantage for speed, in the same color as Stone Rain.
~ + Lightning Bolt: 1 less CMC as Stone Rain, loses card advantage for speed, in the same color as Stone Rain.
~ + Eradicate: 2 more CMC than Stone Rain, exiles target and lobotomizes its controller for that land.

Eradicate is the only option mentioned that is noticeably different from Stone Rain, and is a very powerful effect, akin to Enchanted Evening Scour and Liquimetal Coating Splinter.

Emphasized Stone Rain for emphasis because of all the suggestions that are virtually identical to Stone Rain.

21379: Skyshroud Poacher.author: JaxsonBateman
21379: Skyshroud Poacher.text_parsed:
@Designer Genes - that's just plain silly. Not only is this a card advantage engine, but it let's you search your library for *any* elf permanent card and put it onto the battlefield at instant speed. Being able to get a creature onto the battlefield each turn regardless of what you draw is just damn great. Having Nissa's third ability on a stick is just damn great.

But yes, this should go in a LOT of elf decks. At 4 mana it might be too expensive for some of the more aggressive variants, but for a lot of them, the card advantage and tutoring this card provides is more than enough to warrant inclusion.

21381: Saproling Burst.author: da-odd-templar
21381: Saproling Burst.text_parsed:
For you newer players, let me explain the power of this card.

First turn - Birds of Paradise or Llanowar Elves
Second turn - Fires of Yavimaya
Third Turn - Blastoderm, attack for 5
Fourth Turn - Saproling Burst, make 3 4/4's, attack with them and the Blastoderm. Even if the opponent has a blocker, he's going to block the Blastoderm, and he'll be at 3.

That means even if he did use something like Wrath of God, he was dead to a lowly Lllanowar Elf next turn, because of the Fires of Yavimaya

I beat so many people at FNM's with that deck...it wasn't even fair. Let's not even talk about how unfair Flametongue Kavu was!

21381: Saproling Burst.author: SAllison87
21381: Saproling Burst.text_parsed:
Saproling Burst is usually used as a combo card with Fires of Yavimaya. A turn one Birds of Paradise followed by a T2 Fires of Yavimaya allowed a T3 5/5 Shroud Haste via Blastoderm.
This combo, if followed up by a T4 Saproling Burst, usually spelled doom to Standard players circa 2000-2001 season.
This strategy was developed by Magic Hall Of Fame player Zvi Moshowitz.

21381: Saproling Burst.author: blurrymadness
21381: Saproling Burst.text_parsed:
Even without shenanigans it'll be 3 3/3s or 4 2/2s attacking on T6; combine that with any green finisher card and this will end the game; it may end the game right there anyway (just like a precursor golem.)

With combos, it wins the turn it hits fairly often; which is between T4 and T5.


Also interesting is that the second clause is largely unnecessary. The first clause means they should be 0/0s when this leaves play, making destroying them not only redundant but ineffective (as they'll already be gone due to statebased effects) unless you have global pumps, which at the time were mostly white. Better safe than sorry though I guess.

By the way, this is good in fungus decks that utilize saprolings. This could be a 6 mana ramp, food for a mycoloth, +6/+6 or -6/-6 spread however you want, it could be proliferated (as fungus like to do due to their love of spore counters) and more.

It gets better! This next to a Nantuko Husk provides you with a 14/14 attacker. This next to Xathrid Demon hits an opponent for 6, then for 7 in the air, then for 4 the next turn.

21385: Saproling Cluster.author: Ragamander
21385: Saproling Cluster.text_parsed:
Combos well with Fecundity and Ashnod's Altar.

Ex.
T1: Forest, Llanowar Elves
T2: Forest, Ashnod's Altar
T3: Forest, Tap Llanowar Elves, Fecundity, sacrifice Llanowar Elves, Saproling Cluster, make and sacrifice saprolings until you find (a) Helix Pinnacle or (b) any artifact source that can immediately produce red mana (i.e. Heart of Ramos) and then Banefire.

If you dump in one of the elemental incarnations or Progenitus, you can go truly infinite.

21392: Eye of Yawgmoth.author: leomistico
21392: Eye of Yawgmoth.text_parsed:
Comparing to Browse:
-is colorless
-its CMC and ability cost are 1 less
-situational: it depends from the creatures you have to sacrifice, and if you don't have any you can't play its ability...
-sacrifice a creature Vs nothing
-variable "dig" Vs constant 5 cards...
-you have to reveal the cards

It's not bad, but I think that you have to sacrifice creature with at least 3-4 power to get some real use, and using it only in response to removal is quite questionable... While Browse is clearly a control card, this isn't because in a control you play a few creature, and you have to protect them, while an aggro deck don't play this because it prefer to play another creature instead. And while you can sacrifice tokens to phyrexian vault or carnage altar (even 0-power tokens), with the eye you don't have many more benefits over them because you have to reveal the cards. The vault and the altar have 1 mana less in their CMC or ability cost, so they may have some advantage over this. While I like Impulse-like mechanism, I'm not very sure with this...

2.5/5

21395: Complex Automaton.author: NARFNra
21395: Complex Automaton.text_parsed:
I actually think this card is kind of neat, to a degree. He's not utterly useless as a blocker at turn {4} if you haven't been playing a permanent for every land. He could theoretically be used to abuse "whenever a creature enters the battlefield" abilities. True, he's costly, but something like Cathars' Crusade lets you essentially cast him as a blocker with "Put a +1/+1 counter on each creature you control.". Power Conduit could also be used to steal the counter he'd get from dropping by.

I think the best combination this guy could possibly get is definitely Confusion in the Ranks, though. Consider; He enters the battlefield, you switch his place with a creature/artifact the enemy controls. Then, their turn rolls around, his ability activates, and he returns to your hand. Repeat for more theft. At the worst, you'll annoy them as they have to keep playing things to get their card back. At best, he'll let you steal someone's Darksteel Reactor and get a new win condition.

So I say this guy's worth a 2.5 or 2. Expensive and a pretty ineffective creature, but still able to have a combo somewhere.

21398: Flowstone Thopter.author: BegleOne
21398: Flowstone Thopter.text_parsed:
Flowstone Thopter isn't a bad card in its niche; if you want an artifact creature or colorless creature as a finisher, it's effective and for a while was one of the best available. A power of 7 is the tipping point to do 20 damage in three turns, and flying is always good to have on a finisher. The ability to give flying at will can be a tactical boon.

What other artifact creature would kill an opponent as fast or as easy as the Thopter when it was printed? Phyrexian Colossus and Colossus of Sardia have tap fees that are more mana intensive than the Thopter's power boost and Phyrexian Dreadnought wasn't too useful until the Stifle trick was around. What other artifact creature is in the conversation? Juggernaut? Mishra's War Machine? Teeka's Dragon?

The Thopter swings hard.

21398: Flowstone Thopter.author: Kryptnyt
21398: Flowstone Thopter.text_parsed:
@BegleOne
You bring up good points, as thopter is priced just right for an oldschool urzatron deck. I have to admit I've never considered it as a finisher. And thanks to things like Wurmcoil Engine and Pentavus, I don't have to. I have used Telethopter though!
Phyrexian Colossus was good because you could actually get away with paying the 8 life by blitzing it out with Tinker or Grim Monolith, or you could untap it with keys if you had them. A 7/1 flyer with an upkeep would be hard to keep going, because it trades with small flying creatures and weak, cheap burn spells.

21399: Tangle Wire.author: Lateralis0ne
21399: Tangle Wire.text_parsed:
It's a great control variant. I can see why STAX used it to great effect, and it continues to pervade Vintage tournaments to this day. I have three now for a control deck I'm running with Smokestack,

PROTIP: have one in the graveyard and one in play, and use Goblin Welder to flip them as the one in play goes on the stack during your upkeep. As far as it was explained to me by a judge, the ability fizzles between the exchange, and you keep a full four counter Tangle Wire without ever having to tap a permanent!
21399: Tangle Wire.text_posted:

21399: Tangle Wire.author: teh_mummy
21399: Tangle Wire.text_parsed: @Lateralis0ne; I dont think thats correct, at the beginning of your upkeep the ability goes on the stack, you respond and switch it with the one in your graveyard, then the ability resolves and you tap your permanents using the last information from the first one. to quote the rules pdf "112.7a Once activated or triggered, an ability exists on the stack independently of its source. Destruction or removal of the source after that time wont affect the ability. Note that some abilities cause a source to do something (for example, Prodigal Sorcerer deals 1 damage to target creature or player) rather than the ability doing anything directly. In these cases, any activated or triggered ability that references information about the source because the effect needs to be divided checks that information when the ability is put onto the stack. Otherwise, it will check that information when it resolves. In both instances, if the source is no longer in the zone its expected to be in at that time, its last known information is used. The source can still perform the action even though it no longer exists."
21399: Tangle Wire.text_posted: @Lateralis0ne; I dont think thats correct, at the beginning of your upkeep the ability goes on the stack, you respond and switch it with the one in your graveyard, then the ability resolves and you tap your permanents using the last information from the first one. to quote the rules pdf "112.7a Once activated or triggered, an ability exists on the stack independently of its source. Destruction or removal of the source after that time wont affect the ability. Note that some abilities cause a source to do something (for example, Prodigal Sorcerer deals 1 damage to target creature or player) rather than the ability doing anything directly. In these cases, any activated or triggered ability that references information about the source because the effect needs to be divided checks that information when the ability is put onto the stack. Otherwise, it will check that information when it resolves. In both instances, if the source is no longer in the zone its expected to be in at that time, its last known information is used. The source can still perform the action even though it no longer exists."

21399: Tangle Wire.author: justicarphaeton
21399: Tangle Wire.text_parsed:
So let me get this straight.

Your Turn: Play Tangle Wire with 4 counters.
Opponent's Turn: They tap 4 permanents
Your Turn: layer it so the fading happens before the tapping; you tap 2 permanents and the Wire itself.
Opponent's Turn: They tap 3 permanents
etc. etc.

What a deceptively one-sided card....
And designwise it's also very clever. Too bad it's the epitome of a griefer card ;p

21399: Tangle Wire.author: blurrymadness
21399: Tangle Wire.text_parsed:
Just like Smokestack, in the hands of a vet (or just someone who understands the stack) you get a massive tempo advantage if you want by forcing the opponent to have a much worse effect.

Keep a throne of geth around to either add counters or get rid of the effects of either artifact (especially smokestack) before they hit you again.

Add a finisher or 3, another sac outlet, and some things that can be done at instant speed so your tempo keeps moving while their halts (think Wayfarer's Bauble or explorer's map)

21401: Belbe's Portal.author: Rendin
21401: Belbe's Portal.text_parsed: I find it extremely disappointing to see so many "THIS IS A MUST FOR AN ELDRAZI DECK" comments.  The entire point of the big Eldrazis is to let the swarm herald their arrival and give the opponent a chance to slow it down.  I understand the Spike mentality entirely, but it completely takes all strategy out of the game to just plop this card on the field and start pumping out your biggest creatures.  It's shameful that so many people play Magic like that these days.

I understand the Spike mentality entirely, but it completely takes all strategy out of the game to just plop this card on the field and start pumping out your biggest creatures.  It's shameful that so many people play Magic like that these days.

21401: Belbe's Portal.author: Alsebra
21401: Belbe's Portal.text_parsed:
@RaikNaSeem - Since the stack resolves in the 'last in, first out' order, the Boomerang triggers first (which returns the Portal), then the ability of the Portal triggers (even though it's not around). You get your creature, then you can recast the Portal.

Your opponent probably should've waited until you were tapped out...or just bounced the creature you just dropped.

22028: Parallax Wave.author: OffensiveBias
22028: Parallax Wave.text_parsed:
Was the errata removed from this card which required it to be in play when the creatures were exiled? If so, this card is insanely broken, and even more so with an Opalescence in play.

Situation: It's your opponent's turn and he or she has 40 Relentless Rats in play and they're about to attack you. You have an Opalescence and Parallax Wave (Parallax Tide can be broken just as easily, but won't save you from this situation) with five counters on it in play.

You remove four of Wave's counters targeting four of his Rats and then remove the fifth targeting Wave itself. The Wave gets exiled, triggering its "Return stuff to play" ability while only itself has been exiled, returning itself to play (with five fresh, new counters, I believe, since Magic treats this new Wave as an entirely new permanent; I've been told it would come into play with none because of a rules change, but don't know if it's true). There are now four abilities on the stack which will exile a Rat upon resolving and you have a fresh Wave to continue exploiting. As long as the Wave leaves play after its "exile a creature" ability has been triggered and before the ability resolves, the creatures it exiles will not return to play once removed.

Even without this infinite combo, it's still "exile up to four target creatures" for 2WW.

22028: Parallax Wave.author: DarkerNectron
22028: Parallax Wave.text_parsed:
Incredibly strong on its own: Parallax Wave acts as a temporary one sided wrath, hides your creatures from wrath, and can be used to re-trigger your creatures ETB effects.

Combos well with Opalescence to permanently exile any number of target creatures or blinking your own creatures thereby triggering ETB effects such as Wall of Omens to allow for infinite draw. Add Enchanted Evening into the mix and you remove everyone else's boards.

Overall one of the most powerful white enchantments ever printed. And as KikijikiTiki pointed out, proliferate makes this card even better.

22035: Parallax Tide.author: Mode
22035: Parallax Tide.text_parsed:
I would rather stiftle, trickbind or voidslime the trigger when it leaves play if you want to use this card for land removal. That's not only cheaper than Eon Hub, the latter one might also get destroyed which will cause your opponents to get their lands back.

Additionally, this could also find use on yourself:
Given that you control at least five lands, this will return all of them untapped.
Cast High Tide for instance, then Parallax Tide, remove your islands, get them back, and tap all of them again to get 10 blue mana.
With accordant Landfall abilities, this will be even more fun since you will trigger each of them five times. This will charge all of your Landfall Quests, Hedron Crab for example will mill 15 cards, Lotus Cobra provide 5 mana of any color, Emeria Angel five 1/1 white bird tokens and Rampaging Baloths five 4/4 beast tokens. If you equipped Adventuring Gear on that one, have fun attacking with a 16/16 fattie trampler.

22035: Parallax Tide.author: OneFishTwoFish
22035: Parallax Tide.text_parsed:
@Hunter06: You can't ramp with Parallax Tide unless you tap and exile your lands in response to the fading trigger during your next upkeep. You'd only have the mana during your upkeep, although you could easily go from five mana to ten mana. Or much more, if you're playing something like Tolarian Academy.

You might be confusing Fading with Vanishing.
Fading makes you sacrifice the permanent when a counter can't be removed by the upkeep trigger.
Vanishing makes you sacrifice the permanent whenever the last counter is removed.


@Ragamander, @xlinplips, and @blurrymadness: You could also wait a turn, tap for (or more), exile four of your own lands, and cast Armageddon. They have mana for an extra turn, but the subsequent setback is far stronger than Limited Resources, Cataclysm, or Sunder...or even Balance if you have five or more lands.

22061: Overlaid Terrain.author: ArturoB616
22061: Overlaid Terrain.text_parsed: This card isnt the best card, but its a fun card in a casual deck or a big multiplayer game. A fun strategy to use this card in a casual deck is to use mana ramp spells to lay out your lands fast, then you can use cards like entomb to put realm razer into your graveyard. You then tap all you lands to float your mana, play a spell similar to reanimate targeting realm razer, then with your remaining mana cast this enchantment and then you can choose to use realm razer as a beat stick or sacrifice foder to get your lands back thus by pass this cards weak point. not the best mana accelerant but a fun combo card

22061: Overlaid Terrain.author: Mode
22061: Overlaid Terrain.text_parsed:
This card is currently a bit underrated in my opinion.
It's in fact rather unplayable in general, but this card has interesting combo potential.
You could for example get some mana accel to play this card earlier, or Crucible of Worlds combined with effects that let you put more lands into play, like Exploration.
Or, possibly even better:

/edit note: I wrote nonsense here /
Put it into play without being required to pay its cost and evade the entire drawback. Take a close look at this card: as opposed to most cards with such an devasting drawback, it doesn't trigger when the card enters, it's an additional cost instead.
Therefore you can put it into play with cards like Academy Rector, Show and Tell, Wargate, Replenish, Reweave, Lost Auramancers, Gate to the Æther, Hypergenesis, Eureka, Warp World or Open the Vaults.
The latter cards, especially Open the Vaults, might be not that adviceable if you only want to put that card into play.
What a pity Zur the Enchanter can't fetch this card :/
/ Misinformed nonsense end /

Edit (since 2009):
Silly me.
I somehow misread the card "As additional cost to play Overlaid Terrain, sacrifice all lands you control."
Sorry for the messup!

Still, I got another gamble for those of you who like to try weird stuff: Try ramping into this on turn two with Orcish Lumberjack by saccing a Taiga or Stomping Ground, then you won't have to sacrifice any lands when it enters, and still get to play your second land which immediately produces two mana of any color.
Combine that with the stuff I said above years ago (before the BS-paragraph which I kept for reference),
and you have a fun gimmick deck.

22318: Kill Switch.author: endersblade
22318: Kill Switch.text_parsed:
I have an artifact hate EDH deck. This card is definitely one of the more useful cards in it. It's amazing how many people rely heavily on artifacts in this format; this one card can cause enough grief to make people scoop.

Play it, tap everything down. Opponents play something new, or find ways of untapping their artifacts, bounce it or drop a voltaic key or something that can untap it, then tap it again and re-lock everything down. This thing is brutal. Fatestitcher with something like Instill Energy or Umbral Mantle, and Mycosynth Lattice and it's pretty much game over.
22318: Kill Switch.text_posted:
I have an artifact hate EDH deck.  This card is definitely one of the more useful cards in it.  It's amazing how many people rely heavily on artifacts in this format; this one card can cause enough grief to make people scoop.

This thing is brutal.  [autocard]Fatestitcher[/autocard] with something like [autocard]Instill Energy[/autocard] or [autocard]Umbral Mantle[/autocard], and [autocard]Mycosynth Lattice[/autocard] and it's pretty much game over.

22320: Silkenfist Fighter.author: Mode
22320: Silkenfist Fighter.text_parsed:
I was just browsing TV Tropes when i realized i never actually read this card's flavor text, since it was used as the introductionary quote for the Weapon of Choice trope "Simple Staff".
Now we need a Simple Staff equipment that's as awesome as the trope suggests it ought to be! :D
Since this card is a kor and these folks just coincidentally happen to be great martial artists (or at least the newer ones are particularly good with equipment), i could imagine this equipment providing a bonus if it's equipped to a kor.
(For example this card's trigger, or a further bonus like a +1/+1 boost, first strike or similar stuff.)

Well, about the trigger: in general it's mostly a bad version of Vigilance, but i could imagine some borderline uses where it's preferable (e.g. through cards triggering on permanents tapping/untapping).

22881: Ensnare.author: jeff-heikkinen
22881: Ensnare.text_parsed: "Tap all creatures" has never gotten much Constructed traction, probably because it's unusual for there to be more than about two creatures to tap, at which point you're better off running removal. It is, however, underappreciated in Limited. When I was first learning Sealed, the conventional wisdom in my area was that "tap all creatures" came fairly close to "win target game" in Limited, especially Sealed; it's fairly common there to have a sizable army, with combined power easily exceeding your opponent's life total, that you dare not go all-in with for one reason or another. And if you can't arrange that, at the very least this will grant you a short reprieve from taking damage and usually afford you some kind of substantial free swipe at your opponent into the bargain. This may be the best version of that ability there is, playable on your opponent's turn for no mana; I didn't play much Masquerade Cycle limited, but I'd have probably given serious consideration to splashing for this.

22889: Rootwater Thief.author: kiseki
22889: Rootwater Thief.text_parsed:
@Kirbster
Mike Long was both an extremely talented player (got close to hall of fame status) and a cheater. Ironically, he was so good that he didn't really need to cheat.

Make no mistake, he was caught cheating; this is undisputed. But he did a TON for magic. He increased early popularity of big events, he created the first tournament caliber combo deck (pros-bloom), could bluff his way to victory against top players, and he won an invitational event (and thus the honor of creating this card).

Also, since Mark Rosewater wanted there to be a "bad guy" to make events more interesting, he played it up about him. Thus tons of people hated him enough to make him a popular player to watch. In one event, he got to the semi final and lost. Fewer people watched the final because they had no one to cheer against.

He is a polarizing figure.

Note that well after he quit playing, he was up to be voted on for the Hall of Fame, and he was asked to say a few words about it. If not for this moment, I'd be sympathetic. He responded by belittling and dismissing magic and its accomplishments.
22889: Rootwater Thief.text_posted:
@Kirbster 
Mike Long was both an extremely talented player (got close to hall of fame status) and a cheater.  Ironically, he was so good that he didn't really need to cheat.

Make no mistake, he was caught cheating; this is undisputed.  But he did a TON for magic.  He increased early popularity of big events, he created the first tournament caliber combo deck (pros-bloom), could bluff his way to victory against top players, and he won an invitational event (and thus the honor of creating this card).  

Also, since Mark Rosewater wanted there to be a "bad guy" to make events more interesting, he played it up about him.  Thus tons of people hated him enough to make him a popular player to watch.  In one event, he got to the semi final and lost.  Fewer people watched the final because they had no one to cheer against.  

He is a polarizing figure.

Note that well after he quit playing, he was up to be voted on for the Hall of Fame, and he was asked to say a few words about it.  If not for this moment, I'd be sympathetic.  He responded by belittling and dismissing magic and its accomplishments.

22890: Rathi Assassin.author: The-Earth-Dragon
22890: Rathi Assassin.text_parsed:
Versatile Card.

@jsttu Please do a search with the advanced options to see all the cards with with 1 power this card could block on the first turn for you. Also, please do a search for all the cards that can deal 1 damage to a creature. A prodigal wizard holds a Royal assassin at bay, but not this guy. As others have stated, the mercenary search ability is fantastic, it's the support that is bad. If I'm going to grade a card/ability of a card, I go off it's potential. Unfortunately, one 4 star card (which is what I gave it) doesn't make a good deck when the rest of the cards you'd have to place with it are 1 and 2 star cards. Instead it collects dust until some 3-5 star cards are around to supplement. That's the difference between individual card strength and deck strength.

I'm not saying your comment was outlandish, but it was overly eccentric.

play it.

Use the over-sized beaters ([autocard]skyshroud ridgeback[/autocard], [autocard]leatherback baloth[/autocard], etc) and any anti-flyer tech you might need.

Probably run him alongside [autocard]terra stomper[/autocard] so you have both anti-damage/destroy and anti-blue in the same deck.
